data.title: The Albert Film Institute: 97 Years, 97 Films
data.meta_description: On Facebook, my friend Zack made a post asking for his friends to chime in with movies that they themselves saw as important to watch.  Not necessarily because they were good movies (though that's always a plus), but because they were important to the people who watched them.  Initially, I chimed in with…
data.text:
On Facebook, my friend Zack made a post asking for his friends to chime in with movies that they themselves saw as important to watch. Not necessarily because they were good movies (though that’s always a plus), but because they were important to the people who watched them. Initially, I chimed in with 1989’s Cinema Paradiso, as I was at Best Buy just doing a quick Facebook check. But once I got home, I wondered what else I could recommend, and decided to do a year-by-year analysis of all the films in my Blu-Ray and DVD collection, then pick one film from each year that I felt most strongly as my favorite of the moment. Some choices were obvious to me (1980’s Somewhere in Time or last year’s Sing Street), but I became conflicted with a few others. Would I pick something because it was my favorite, or would I pick it because I wanted to recommend it to Zack? Or maybe I’d pick it because it’s a universally-agreed-upon great movie?

Ultimately, I decided to always pick movies that I wanted to watch, regardless if I were recommending it for someone else or not. And for years where I couldn’t pick just one movie (it’s such a Sophie’s Choice when I’m asked to pick between Bell, Book and Candle or Vertigo), I’d list the other as “Honorable Mention,” basically implying that it’s a tie. The 97 films chosen (and 16 honorable mentions) surely aren’t going to please everyone (I doubt anyone will find as much joy in 1984’s Supergirl as I do), but it’s my list and I’ll do what I want with it. Eventually, I’ll do more with this list; maybe I’ll write a paragraph about each film and why it’s here. For now, just enjoy a list of great movies as decided by the Albert Film Institute.

The Kid (1921, Charlie Chaplin)

Nosferatu (1922, F.W. Murnau)

Safety Last! (1923, Fred Newmeyer & Sam Taylor)

The Last Laugh (1924, F.W. Murnau)

The Freshman (1925, Fred Newmeyer & Sam Taylor)

The Temptress (1926, Fred Niblo)

Sunrise, A Song of Two Humans (1927, F.W. Murnau)

The Mysterious Lady (1928, Fred Niblo)

The Cocoanuts (1929, Robert Florey & Joseph Santley)

Morocco (1930, Josef von Sternberg)

Platinum Blonde (1931, Frank Capra) / Honorable Mention: Frankenstein (James Whale)

Blonde Venus (1932, Josef von Sternberg)

Footlight Parade (1933, Lloyd Bacon & Busby Berkeley)

It Happened One Night (1934, Frank Capra)

Anna Karenina (1935, Clarence Brown)

Modern Times (1936, Charlie Chaplin)

Make Way for Tomorrow (1937, Leo McCarey)

Bringing Up Baby (1938, Howard Hawks)

Golden Boy (1939, Rouben Mamoulian)

The Thief of Bagdad (1940, Michael Powell, Ludwig Berger, & Tim Whelan)

Ball of Fire (1941, Howard Hawks)

Casablanca (1942, Michael Curtiz) / Honorable Mention: Random Harvest (Mervyn LeRoy)

Best Foot Forward (1943, Edward Buzzell)

Laura (1944, Otto Preminger)

Brief Encounter (1945, David Lean)

Gilda (1946, Charles Vidor) / A Matter of Life and Death (Michael Powell & Emeric Pressburger)

Nightmare Alley (1947, Edmund Goulding)

The Red Shoes (1948, Michael Powell & Emeric Pressburger)

The Heiress (1949, William Wyler)

Sunset Blvd. (1950, Billy Wilder)

A Place in the Sun (1951, George Stevens)

Singin’ in the Rain (1952, Gene Kelly & Stanley Donen)

The Band Wagon (1953, Vincente Minnelli)

Sabrina (1954, Billy Wilder)

East of Eden (1955, Elia Kazan)

The Ten Commandments (1956, Cecil B. DeMille)

Peyton Place (1957, Mark Robson)

Bell, Book and Candle (1958, Richard Quine) / Honorable Mention: Vertigo (Alfred Hitchcock)

Some Like It Hot (1959, Billy Wilder)

Breathless (1960, Jean-Luc Godard)

Splendor in the Grass (1961, Elia Kazan)

The Manchurian Candidate (1962, John Frankenheimer)

It’s a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World (1963, Stanley Kramer)

Mary Poppins (1964, Robert Stevenson) / Honorable Mention: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (Jacques Demy)

The Sound of Music (1965, Robert Wise)

How to Steal a Million (1966, William Wyler)

The Graduate (1967, Mike Nichols)

The Beatles: Yellow Submarine (1968, George Dunning)

Hello, Dolly! (1969, Gene Kelly)

Kes (1970, Ken Loach) / Honorable Mention: Ryan’s Daughter (David Lean)

Bedknobs and Broomsticks (1971, Robert Stevenson)

What’s Up, Doc? (1972, Peter Bogdanovich)

The Wicker Man (1973, Robin Hardy)

Claudine (1974, John Berry)

The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975, Jim Sharman)

Network (1976, Sidney Lumet)

Pete’s Dragon (1977, Don Chaffey)

Grease (1978, Randal Kleiser)

Manhattan (1979, Woody Allen)

Somewhere in Time (1980, Jeannot Szwarc)

Mommie Dearest (1981, Frank Perry)

Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982, Nicholas Meyer) / Honorable Mention: Tootsie (Sydney Pollack)

Educating Rita (1983, Lewis Gilbert)

Supergirl (1984, Jeannot Szwarc)

Clue: The Movie (1985, Jonathan Lynn)

A Room with a View (1986, James Ivory)

Empire of the Sun (1987, Steven Spielberg) / Honorable Mention: Wings of Desire (Wim Wenders)

Who Framed Roger Rabbit? (1988, Robert Zemeckis)

Cinema Paradiso (1989, Giuseppe Tornatore) / Honorable Mention: When Harry Met Sally… (Rob Reiner)

Ghost (1990, Jerry Zucker)

Beauty and the Beast (1991, Kirk Wise & Gary Trousdale)

Aladdin (1992, Ron Clements & John Musker) / Honorable Mention: Sister Act (Emile Ardolino)

Mrs. Doubtfire (1993, Chris Columbus)

Il Postino (1994, Michael Radford)

Before Sunrise (1995, Richard Linklater)

The First Wives Club (1996, Hugh Wilson) / Honorable Mention: Everyone Says I Love You (Woody Allen)

Titanic (1997, James Cameron)

The Legend of 1900 (1998, Giuseppe Tornatore)

Cruel Intentions (1999, Roger Kumble) / Honorable Mention: October Sky (Joe Johnston)

Chocolat (2000, Lasse Hallström)

Moulin Rouge! (2001, Baz Luhrmann)

About a Boy (2002, Chris Weitz & Paul Weitz)

I Capture the Castle (2003, Tim Fywell)

A Very Long Engagement (2004, Jean-Pierre Jeunet) / Honorable Mentions: Howl’s Moving Castle (Hayao Miyazaki), Before Sunset (Richard Linklater)

Brokeback Mountain (2005, Ang Lee) / Honorable Mention: Kingdom of Heaven (Ridley Scott)

Paris, je t’aime (2006, Emmanuel Benbihy, Frédéric Auburtin, Bruno Podalydès, Paul Mayeda Berges & Gurinder Chadha, Gus Van Sant, Joel & Ethan Coen, Walter Salles & Daniela Thomas, Christopher Doyle, Isabel Coixet, Nobuhiro Suwa, Sylvain Chomet, Alfonso Cuarón, Olivier Assayas, Oliver Schmitz, Richard LaGravenese, Vincenzo Natal, Wes Craven, Tom Tykwer, Frédéric Auburtin & Gérard Depardieu, Alexander Payne)

Stardust (2007, Matthew Vaughn) / Honorable Mention: The History Boys (Nicholas Hytner)

Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008, Bharat Nalluri)

Star Trek (2009, J.J. Abrams)

Easy A (2010, Bert V. Royal)

Midnight in Paris (2011, Woody Allen) / Honorable Mention: Weekend (Andrew Haigh)

The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012, Stephen Chbosky)

Before Midnight (2013, Richard Linklater)

The Theory of Everything (2014, James Marsh)

Brooklyn (2015, John Crowley) / Honorable Mention: Cinderella (Kenneth Branagh)

Sing Street (2016, John Carney)

Newsies (2017, Brett Sullivan)

As 2017 still has ten months left to wow me, my current selection is very much an “in the moment” choice. Plus, it was either that or The Lego Batman Movie. As much as I love both, Newsies clearly is the better film. But let’s see what else the cinema has to offer. There’s plenty of films that have caught my eye which I’ll want to see this year, from blockbusters to dramas to sci-fi epics, including: Baby Driver (Edgar Wright), Beauty and the Beast (Bill Condon), The Book of Henry (Colin Trevorrow), Call Me By Your Name (Luca Guadagnino), Dunkirk (Christopher Nolan), The Lovers (Azazel Jacobs), Murder on the Orient Express (Kenneth Branagh), My Cousin Rachel (Roger Michell), The Sense of an Ending (Ritesh Batra), Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (Luc Besson), and Wonder Woman (Patty Jenkins).

Also, Descendants 2 comes out this summer. Shut up.

I’ll be seeing you…
